awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Modeling the singular and additive effects of various anthropogenic disturbances using genomics
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The Fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. Species are often affected by multiple human-created stressors simultaneously. However, disentangling the singular and additive effects of these human made stressors remains challenging. The fellow will use a technique called landscape genomics, which allows you to identify relationships between the environment and genetics of organisms, to build a model to understand the effect of human induced environmental change (urbanization, climate change) on a freshwater turtle, the Puerto Rican Slider, in Puerto Rico. This species is impacted by both habitat loss to urbanization and the spread of an invasive species, the red eared slider. Additionally, the fellow will facilitate community engagement at various levels. Firstly, the fellow will work with Puerto Rican science educators to facilitate the use of iNaturalist, which is an app used to discover, identify and report local biodiversity. Secondly, the fellow will facilitate training in molecular laboratory techniques for underrepresented high school students near the sponsoring institution in New York. Thirdly, the fellow will help connect students to graduate programs, fellowships, and professional opportunities through a Facebook group called Jicoteando created for this fellowship and also via various oral presentations.   

This research will require the application of population genomics, spatial analyses, and ecological studies. Thus, the fellow will be provided training in many new skills and in interdisciplinary work. The landscape genomics models will test the singular and additive contributions of biotic and abiotic factors in relation to the species’ functional genetic connectivity. To accomplish this, the fellow will first sequence genomic DNA and then sample relevant landscape and ecological covariates across the study area. Covariates will then be transformed into resistance surfaces characterizing their permeability or resistance to the movement of genetic variation. This transformation will be used to contrast singular and additive resistances arising from the measured covariates. The fellow will build important collaborations with conservation agencies with the goal of writing a management plan for the species informed by the impacts of landscape features and hybridization. The fellow will also gain outreach experience working with students at various career stages.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Title: Evaluating the compounded effects of anthropogenic environmental change on an understudied Puerto Rican Slider Turtle

Introduction: Many species face elevated extinction risk due to the ecosystem changes wrought by humans and human activity. For example, some species are vulnerable due to the compounded effects of habitat loss, and the introduction of non-native species. Turtles in particular are highly vulnerable due to human activity. Nearly half of the known turtle species are vulnerable to extinction. Yet, some species are heavily understudied. Our project set out to evaluate the impacts of urban landscape and competition with an invasive turtle in the Puerto Rican Slider Turtle. 

Project Goals: Ouf funded project aimed to achieve the following goals: 

  1. Evaluate the current status of the Puerto Rican Slider Turtle: The Puerto Rican Slider Turtle, is a freshwater turtle whose range extends from the eastern coast of the islands of Dominican Republic and throughout Puerto Rico. Puerto Rican conservation agencies listed the species in an endangered species list, but due to a lack of studies, no conservation plan currently exists. We sought to evaluate the population status of the Puerto Rican Slider  across the island of Puerto Rico. In particular, we aimed to explore whether the turtle thrives in highly urbanized wetlands which are common in the coastal habitats where the species is documented to be more abundant. 

  2. Evaluate the impacts of the spread of invasive Red-eared sliders: Red-eared Sliders have a native range that extends from south-central U.S. states into parts of Northern Mexico. Red-eared Sliders heavily exported out of the United States as a commercial pet species. Consequently, they have become invasive with a nearly global distribution and are currently listed as one of the 100 worst invasive species. In Puerto Rico, local conservation agencies are concerned that Red-eared Sldiers are competing with  the native turtle and that the species are interbreeding resulting in hybrids. We sought to document the establishment of Red-eared sliders throughout Puerto Rico and use genetics to evaluate hybridization between the native and invasive turtles on the island.

Discoveries and breakthroughs: 

  1. Population status of the Puerto Rican Slider: Our research revealed that the Puerto Rican Slider can thrive in highly degraded and urbanized wetlands. However, whether juvenile turtles survive to adulthood at all wetlands remains largely unknown and was outside of the scope of our research. 

  2.  Impacts of the Red-eared slider: We found Red-eared sliders were abundant throughout the island of Puerto Rico and in at least three wetlands we found evidence of wild reproduction. Red-eared sliders thrived in wetlands where the people could access the water easily. Additionally, these wetlands were frequently visited by people who fed turtles and other animals like water fowl. Our genetic study confirmed the presence of hybrids and that these hybrids can reproduce with both species. The reproductive viability of hybrids suggests that conservation plans should consider preserving the genetic diversity of the Puerto Rican Slider. Additionally, community outreach is critical to curtail behaviors that help spread Red-eared sliders and can be harmful to wildlife.

 

Impact on Society: 

  1. Conserving the Puerto Rican Slider: We presented this research at the Turtle Survival Alliance Conference where there had been virtually no updates on this or any other Caribbean species since the early 1990s. Consequently, I will be collaborating with the Tortoise and Freshwater Turtle Specialist Group to update the status of Puerto Rican Slider on the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). Presently the Puerto Rican Slider was last revised on 2004. The discoveries of this research will be published in a Spanish Book Biodiversidad de Puerto Rico (?Biodiversity of Puerto Rico?). Additionally, through this research, we currently maintain a Facebook Group ?Jicoteando? where we provide access to science education and resources to drive community engagement in conserving Puerto Rican Biodiversity. 

  2. Impacts of the Red-eared Slider: We have reported our findings of wild reproduction and hybridization with the invasive Red-eared slider to local and federal conservation agencies in Puerto Rico. Within our report, we provide recommendations to aid the management of this invasive species including the special designation of highly urbanized wetlands as sinks for any invasive turtle captured in protected wetlands. 

Conclusion:  

Our NSF-funded research produced important data critical for accessing the current viability of the Puerto Rican Slider and the potential impacts of the invasive Red-Eared Sliders. Considering how multiple facets of human activity affect species will be important in tailoring conservation plans for any species. For example, our research suggest that invasive turtles are thriving in part due to human feeding at areas like botanical gardens and urban parks. Thus, conservation plans will need to include outreach and education of local communities to curtail behaviors which can be harmful to wildlife. We are grateful to the NSF for funding this research.
